name: Krishna
title: Hindu - Krishna
description:
Krishna stands as one of the most revered and multifaceted figures in Hindu mythology. 

According to Hindu sacred texts, Krishna's origins represent eternal aspects of Brahman, cycling through cosmic ages and divine incarnations The worship of Krishna became central to Hindu religious practice, with devotees seeking their favor through puja ceremonies, bhakti devotion, and sacred pilgrimages. 

Sacred symbols associated with Krishna include hindu symbolism. These emblems appear throughout Hindu art and literature, serving as powerful reminders of Krishna's divine presence and authority. The mythology surrounding Krishna reveals deep insights into Hindu worldview, particularly concerning unknown and humanity's relationship with the divine. 

The legacy of Krishna extends far beyond ancient Hindu civilization. Krishna continues to receive active worship by millions of devotees. The deity's philosophy and practices have influenced yoga, meditation, and spiritual movements globally Scholars continue to study Krishna's mythology for its profound insights into Hindu culture, religion, and philosophy.

cultural_significance: A significant deity in hindu mythology, widely worshipped and culturally influential.

topic_panels.title: Origins & Mythology
topic_panels.content:
### Sacred Origins

Krishna's mythology cosmic ocean, Brahman manifestation, trimurti. The deity's role in Hindu cosmology reflects fundamental aspects of how ancient peoples understood divine power and cosmic order.

### Creation Accounts

Primary sources describe Krishna's emergence and divine nature through various sacred narratives. These origin stories served both religious and cultural functions, establishing divine authority and cosmic principles.

**Time Period:** c. 1500 BCE - present

topic_panels.title: Worship & Practice
topic_panels.content:
### Religious Practice

Worship of Krishna involved puja, bhakti, pilgrimage, festivals. These practices created sacred bonds between devotees and the divine realm.

### Sacred Sites

Throughout Indian subcontinent, temples and shrines dedicated to Krishna served as focal points for religious activity. Priests and priestesses maintained sacred rituals that ensured divine favor and cosmic balance.

### Festivals & Ceremonies

Special festivals celebrated Krishna's divine attributes and mythological deeds, bringing communities together in shared religious expression.

topic_panels.title: Symbols & Iconography
topic_panels.content:
### Sacred Symbols

Key symbols associated with Krishna:

- **hindu symbolism**: Represents divine power and sacred authority

### Divine Attributes

The iconography reveals how ancient peoples visualized divine power and cosmic forces.

### Artistic Representations

Ancient artworks depict Krishna with distinctive attributes that communicate divine identity and authority to worshippers.

topic_panels.title: Modern Influence
topic_panels.content:
### Cultural Legacy

Yoga, meditation, New Age spirituality. The mythology of Krishna continues to resonate in contemporary culture, literature, and spiritual practices.

### Academic Study

Modern scholars analyze Krishna's mythology through multiple lenses‚Äîreligious studies, anthropology, archaeology, and comparative mythology‚Äîrevealing insights into ancient worldviews.

### Popular Culture

Krishna appears in modern media, from fantasy novels to video games, demonstrating the enduring power of ancient mythology to capture human imagination and address timeless questions.

related_myths.title: Krishna and the Sacred Quest

related_myths.title: Krishna and the Divine Council
related_myths.summary: Stories of Krishna's interactions with other deities, revealing the complex relationships and hierarchies of the Hindu pantheon.

related_myths.title: The Legacy of Krishna
related_myths.summary: How Krishna's actions and teachings continue to influence the world, establishing sacred traditions and cosmic principles.
